text: That's right -- there is a fine line.  And I want to do my best to stay on the right side of that line. And yes: people are better than their worst moments in life.
author: KirstenPowers

text: thank you -- i don't plan on changing that.  I am more interested in working on the "judgy" part that comes out mostly on Twitter and my columns, but can seep into commentary from time to time
author: KirstenPowers

text: TY but i know i can do better than what i've done, esp here on Twitter.  There is a way to stand up for what you believe without rushing to judgment ... and that includes even after all the facts are in. there is something to be said for taking time to think about an issue...
author: KirstenPowers

text: There is a way to hold people accountable and not be judgmental. Also i really do believe people are not the sum of their worst moments in life and too often in the media we make it seem like they are.
author: KirstenPowers

text: yes that's the challenge ... but if I can't figure out a way to do this in a way that is consistent with who I want to be then I'll have to find another career....
author: KirstenPowers

text: exactly! i've worked so hard to not be a hypocrite but then became someone sitting in judgement in every situation to try and stay consistent....just as bad.
author: KirstenPowers

text: 8)  I also hope to be part of a conversation -- if we ever have it as a country -- about the path to redemption for people who have stumbled and even failed spectacularly.  This is where I plan to put my focus and not on rendering judgements about other people's behavior. THE END
author: KirstenPowers

text: 7) I often am too rigid in trying to be pure in my principles and don't leave enough room for this mess of life.  So I'm writing this as an apology to both left and right and making a pledge to do better.
author: KirstenPowers

text: 6) It should be said I have been an equal opportunity scold, and liberals have been on the receiving end of my judgement and I regret that as well. I am rethinking my view on Al Franken, for example, after hearing from many friends on the issue of the rush to judgement.
author: KirstenPowers

text: 5) I also don't believe these teenagers should be tarnished forever for what amounts to one really bad day. I know that black teenage boys don't get this benefit of the doubt or grace, but I want more black teenage boys to get this benefit, not fewer white teenage boys.
author: KirstenPowers

text: 4)  Yes, this applies in the Covington case. This will please nobody because I still believe the teenagers were disrespectful, but my tweets were lacking in grace. As a Catholic I felt duty bound to speak up and hold them accountable, but that really isn't my job.
author: KirstenPowers

text: 3) I want to stand on the side of justice and equality but also of grace and I have failed to do that. Part of grace is recognizing my own fallibilities and imperfect judgment and reminding myself that there but for the grace of God go I.
author: KirstenPowers

text:
2) I work hard to see
every side of an issue and also speak up when I see a wrong.  But in
doing that I am too often judgmental and condemning--both on and off social media--in a way that is
contrary to my belief system and my faith.
author: KirstenPowers

text: 1) I have spent the last few weeks in a mostly Twitter free zone to spend time reflecting on what role I may have played in what indisputably has become a dangerously toxic culture.  I am not proud of what I have found.
author: KirstenPowers

text:
5/5 "A Rockefeller Foundation study found that when a company is in crisis, 80 percent of news reports will blame a female CEO — but if the CEO is a man, only a minority of news reports will blame him."  via @joannelipman in @usatoday 

Go read the whole column now!
author: KirstenPowers

text: 4) @joannelipman also points out that women are more likely to get the job when a company is in crisis (which CBS is) making success more difficult, and studies show that the media is harder on women CEO's than male when they fail. (So keep your eyes out for this in coverage!)
author: KirstenPowers

text: 3)  In the US, "more than 70% of Sunday morning politics/policy talk show guests are male. One study of English-language news sites...found that 77 percent of those mentioned in articles are men...women are “routinely marginalized or ‘symbolically annihilated’ in the news.”
author: KirstenPowers

text:
2) "Zirinsky, the first woman ever to head up CBS News, is 66 years old. She has been working at the network for 46 years — which means she started a year before the executive she’s replacing, David Rhodes, was born."

text: 4/4 actually one more -- my ultimate point is that the media in covering this needs to not act like it's just a mystery that @RashidaTlaib is being dragged but everyone shrugs when it's Trump.  Don't participate in dragging her for something Trump gets a pass on.
author: KirstenPowers

text: 3/3 Also let's let's not take complaints from the religious right about @RashidaTlaib seriously when they could care less about DJT using the exact same word she used (and more).
author: KirstenPowers

text: 2/ Where were the shrieking headlines when Trump said the same word she used? We need to be clear that there is a major double standard here: white man can curse but if a woman, esp a brown one, esp a Muslim one does it....she will be punished...
author: KirstenPowers

text: 1/Respectfully disagree w/my colleague @CillizzaCNN. He says, "People don't hold Trump to the same standards that they hold other politicians to." Therefore, he argues Tlaib (and thus Dems) will be punished more for her profanity.  But the reason she's treated differently matters

text:
A good reminder that whenever you speak out about racism those who wish to silence you will try to delegitimize you with toxic labels.  

The new one is to label people calling out white supremacy as “racists.”  Totally Orwellian.
author: KirstenPowers

text: Exactly.
author: KirstenPowers

text: I am and I’ve said that in various interviews and here on Twitter. That doesn’t get posted though does it?
author: KirstenPowers

text:
The piece you wrote is exactly right.  Someone clips something you said, gives it a headline that distorts the actual conversation and then you are threatened and attacked (for me it’s w misogynistic rants) for weeks. 

And most ppl only read the headline.
author: KirstenPowers

text: Also sorry for the typos—A reminder to never write tweets without my glasses LOL
author: KirstenPowers

text: 5/5 I don’t see the point in doing what I do for a living if I’m not going to say hard things or try to start hard conversations. I’m not going to do it perfectly and I wont always choose my words perfectly but my intentions are always to raise awareness of issues, not attack ppl
author: KirstenPowers

text: 4). I’m sure there’s plenty of people who would’ve been angry that I was even talking about the fact that racism is an issue but I doubt I would’ve gotten the relentless attacks if Real Clear Politics hadn’t acted so irresponsibility, esp w the click bait headline
author: KirstenPowers

text: 3) If they had posted the entire interview you would’ve seen that I was trying to have a hard conversation about racism and I said quite clearly that all people – – including liberals — need to contend with their own racism and privilege.
author: KirstenPowers

text: 2) posting click-bait to rile up Trump supporters like Real Clear Politics did resulted in two weeks of nonstop attacks just like the one I posted.  That wasn’t an outlier.  Right wing outlets like @FoxNews and @BrietbartNews picked it up and used it to feed the outrage machine
author: KirstenPowers

text: 1) one of the reasons I posted that message was to show what happens when @RealClearNews posts an video of me discussing racism and edits out the part abt me saying that all white ppl need to face up to their racism to make it seem like I only discussed Trump supporters.
author: KirstenPowers

text:
I just deleted the tweet from the woman calling me “cuntbag” etc  and attacking my dogs b/c I didn’t realize when I posted the screenshot her name showed up.

She is getting attacked and no matter how horrible that message was I have no interest in causing her any harm.
author: KirstenPowers

text:
Pelosi has been known to say: “No one gives you power. You have to take it from them.” 

The leitmotif of her...ascent is that of a woman wresting power away from a male-dominated political machine, until one day the machine discovered she was its master.
author: KirstenPowers

author: KirstenPowers

text: For those upset abt my comments about racism+Trump supporters, I also said that ALL white ppl (not just Trump supporters) need to examine their own racist assumptions/white privilege that are the result of living in a society that privileges white people. That includes me.
author: KirstenPowers

text:
This headline doesn’t capture the whole conversation but the basic point remains: you can’t support a racial demagogue and then claim to not be racist.  

Kirsten Powers: Voting For Trump Because You Didnt Like Hillary Clinton "Doesnt Make You Not Racist"
author: KirstenPowers
